title: My car loan was not reaffirmed, but I kept making payments on my car and it was recently repossessed, will they return if I make
question: the loan current or are they just trying to get more money out of me and will keep the car?
answers: Filing bankruptcy is usually considered a default under the terms of your vehicle loan agreement even if you remain current on the payments. The lender has the right to repossess the vehicle. Usually Ford will do this although most other car companies will allow you to keep the vehicle as long as you remain current. It is usually not a good idea to reaffirm a car loan if you know in the future there is a chance you will fall behind on payments because you will be personally liable for the reaffirmed debt. You can seek to have to bankruptcy opened to reaffirm the debt but it depends on the Judge in your case as to whether it will be allowed. You would need to research the Judge and what his/her stand on the issue is.

When you do not reaffirm the car loan the lender is allowed to repossess the vehicle even if you are current with the payments. You are not liable for the deficiency judgment that may result after they sell the vehicle at auction.

You don't state it, but I'm assuming you filed a Chapter 7 case and the vehicle was repossessed after your case was closed. I'm also going to guess that the lender on your vehicle was Ford or Chrysler. This is one reason having an experienced bankruptcy attorney is worthwhile. It is well known that Ford and Chrysler will repossess vehicles in the absence of a reaffirmation agreement, even if payments remain current.

There isn't much you can do about it. You can call them and see what you can offer to get the vehicle back. But at this point, it's completely up to them. You would have had to do a reaffirmation agreement in order to keep the vehicle--and you're probably better off having it repossessed.
